heading: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1890.
articleText:
SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1890.

The manifesto issued by the Em- ployers' Conference makes clear the points involved in the present wide- spread strike, and the reasons why the

employers have been compelled to offer a firm and united resistance to the demands made upon them and to the menaces which have been hurled at them. The recital of their grievances recalls attention to the events that preceded the strike, and that marked its first stages. It must never be forgotten that boycotting on a large scale was threatened in the most reckless and unscrupulous fashion. Despite every protest the shearers in- voked the aid of the other unionists to block the shipment of non-union wool, and an immense disturbance to the shipping interest was threatened, simply that a few shearers who desired to earn an honest living on their own terms'might be forced either into joining the union or leaving their work altogether. Nor is it possible to forget that the gas stokers were called out for the sole purpose of coercing the company into acceding to every demand of the unions. It was then the policy of the strike committee to sacrifice the public comfort and convenience in the hope of obtaining a partial victory by this un- necessary, unjust, and cruel method. The Trades-hall leaders now say that the method of trades unionism is persuasion. To unionism which rests upon per-

suasion, which uses only legitimate means of convincing the free labourer, and which does not boycott either the employer or the workman, there could not be the slightest objection in any quarter. But the two events to which we have referred meant intimidation in its worst form, and nothing less. Why should the wharf labourers threaten to strike if they were asked to handle a bale of non-union wool ; why were the gas stokers called out as soon as a ton of non-union coal was

landed for the gasworks ? This may be euphemistically described as persuasion, but it exactly corresponds to that moral suasion which consists in starving a be- sieged town into submission. Then, again, when the strike began an effort was made to deprive the free labourers, who had the courage to enter into a legiti- mate calling, of the very necessaries of life. This may also be persuasion, but it reminds one of the method in which a heretical prisoner used to be converted by refusing him food. Ac- cordingly the employers have banded themselves together to resist intimida- tion. They have made no attack upon unionism ; they simply refuse to submit to the tyranny of those irresponsible and mischief-making committees by which the working classes have been

misled.

In this policy there are three dis- tinct issues, which are set forth at length in the resolutions. It is obviously the first duty of the employers to protect the men who are now working for them. The unions have no right to object to them, and still less right to intimidate them. If they choose to remain free they should be at liberty to do so, with- out any fear that they may be driven from their employment. But as the unions have been habitually used to coerce the non-union workman, the employers insist further on the general principle that there must be freedom of contract. In other words union men will be free to work or not as they please, and to put forward whatever demands they may think fair and reasonable, but their power is not to be used to crush other labourers out of existence. And finally, as a combination of unions has been threatening to interfere with the course of trade, the employers pledge them- selves to resist any and every effort at any wholesale boycotting of the sort. If the trades unionists are faithful to the best form of unionism, they should have little difficulty in admitting the sub- stantial justice of these propositions. According to its best exponents and its own best traditions, unionism is based upon persuasion. That form of it which relies upon coercion and com- pulsion has sprung up recently, and in the great congress which has just been held in England the representatives of many societies re- pudiated it. We need not remind the public that it is a poor cause which cannot be advocated by reason, and which must be supported by force. If trades unionism cannot exist without violence and intimidation, then it has served its purpose, and the sooner another system is adopted of arranging the relations between capital and labour, the better will it be for the community. The boycotting system is as hurtful to the working classes as to the public. It restricts the unions and thereby drives men out of employ- ment who are unable to pay high en- trance fees. It places the unions them- selves at the mercy of a few paid agitators, whose policy they have not the courage or the ability to oppose. To no class can a system of in- timidation prove of real and lasting benefit.

To carry out their policy the members of the Employers' Conference recom- mend the formation of a large Em- ployers' Union which would extend over the length and breadth of Aus- tralia. It is suggested that local councils should be established in every colony, and that all these councils should be firmly federated. Such a union, powerful though it will be, has indeed become necessary. There can be no industrial peace if the employers are divided and if they are liable to be

attacked singly by large combinations

of workmen. Of late the union leaders have even shown a tendency to dis- regard agreements which are made with the employers. The Sydney wharf labourers broke an understanding, that had been made after long and careful negotiations, within a few days after it had been formally adopted. Such a spirit would de- stroy enterprise and debar men from extending their business. It must be met in the only effective way by an organisation which is strong enough to see that agreements are respected. And, on the other side, those employers who are accused of being too apt to take every advantage of their workmen will be restrained by the opinion and the policy of the association. If there are two large unions of em- ployers and employed, the potty little industrial struggles which are inces- santly being carried on, and which in the aggregate are expensive and harass- ing, will probably come to an end. And we may presume that the leaders on both sides, knowing what conse- quences a general strike would involve, would use every means of conciliation before resorting to it. It remains to be seen how far the rational method of trades unionism will triumph over intimidation, and whether the unionists are willing to abandon the boycott and rely upon persuasion. If a reasonable and just view is taken of this important point, then the other matters which are in dispute in the shipping trade might speedily be settled to the advantage of

both parties.

Tn nnothor column we publish some trenchant remarks by Mr. R. L. STEVEN- SON, the well-known and deservedly popular novelist, upon tho fiction of tho present day, and especially upon the tendency to what is called realism. The main point of his contention is that the realistic novel is of necessity an inaccurate representation of human life, and that a fairer picture can be formed without entering too elaborately into details, and certainly without sketching minutely the worst vices of mankind. No one can possibly believe that the house described by Zola in one of his most powerful stories, in which all tho residents, from the apparently respectable people on the first floor to tho lodgers in tho attics, are incessantly engaged in vicious intrigues, and in which tho universal hypocrisy is sickening, is to be taken as a true type of Paris. In presenting his picture, ZOLA has to bring the characters together, whereas in real life they would be separated. Hypocrisy and vice do undoubtedly exist, but tho ordinary traveller through

the world does not come across them as

they are described by ZOLA, unrelieved by any virtues or any real happiness. Neither is it true to human nature to be for ever harping upon the moral cor- ruptions, the black spots, which dis- figure it. As Mr. STEVENSON points out, the realistic authors of France have drifted into a one-sided view of that restless, many-coloured humanity which is the subject of their art. Start- ing with the theory that they must copy literally from nature, that it is their duty to describe simply what they see, their gaze is naturally riveted upon the innumerable social impurities, which are omitted from more wholesome books. When they hear joyous laughter, or portray the sunlight in the fields, they are unable to lose consciousness, even for a moment, of tho black cloud of vice. " The " moment," says Mr. STEVENSON, " anything enjoyable appears they must " remind the reader that there is a cess pool under the kitchen floor, a corpse " in the back parlour cupboard, and a " volcano in the immediate vicinity. I do " not say it is not so in real life. I only " say that in life nobody cares. If he " is meeting his sweetheart or combat " ing his enemy at the moment, cess " pool, corpse, and volcano are all blotted " from his mind. He does not look " out of tho window to analyse a smell, " and consider the miserable fate of " humanity, or the geological conditions " of tho earth." There are unlovely things enough in the background of society. But in their tragedies and comedies, in their loves '" ánd quarrels, in their joys and sorrows, people are not constantly thinking of them. The realistic novelist is in danger of acquiring such an all-per- vading consciousness of vice, that his observations of a large part of life are

distorted.

But among novels which are alto- gether free from tho faults of French fiction, there is a tendency to one sidedness and to a minuteness of description that defeats the writer's intention. There are authors who seem to think that the novel is a handy form of stringing together a number of sermons, others who use it to describe in what way a handkerchief might or should or would be carried, others who look upon it as their business to ex- haust all the words at their command in describing clouds and sunsets. Thus it is that we get page after page of the most elaborate descriptions, descriptions of scenery, detailed accounts of dresses, physiological analyses of tho heroine's mind, and all the hundred and one things that prevent the passions and sentiments of tho characters from being displayed naturally. The book is over- loaded and tho reader wearied. The picture which rises before his mind as he turns the leaves is not made clearer by tho wealth of detail in which the writer chooses to indulge. And when, in addition, we find, as we find in the ordinary young lady's novel, that the most humdrum conversations of society are repeated, that there are formal visits with tho usual questions about sisters and cousins and aunts, when tho most trifling incident of an extremely decorous household is made to extend over chapters, then tho mere minuteness becomes unspeak- ably and exasperatingly dreary. The greatest genius could not save such a

book from dulness.

A novel is not necessarily a literal reproduction of what the author may have observed in any domain of human life. It should be a picture of passion and sentiment and character, reasonably true to nature, and so arranged by the skill of the author as to be above all things interesting. For this purpose there is no special need of a mass of details. It might be difficult, for in- stance, to meet a DANDIE DINMONT in real life, but the blustering good-hearted Border farmer is the type of a whole class, and to this day he may be occasionally recognised under very different circum- stances. Few people have over seen CALEB BALDERSTONE in the flesh, but he is a character of extreme interest as the ideal, as tho best type, of a devoted class of servant, which tho traditions of an earlier age created. It is needless to multiply instances. We may say that a novel should contain types of character. Many details may be omitted, tho descriptions can be cut down, tho vices of the world can be assailed without being catalogued and portrayed in all their hideousness. It is enough to appeal to tho great pas- sions and desires of mankind. ACHILLES would have been insignificant if the old Greek poet had given minute descriptions of every day of his life and of every motive that crossed his mind. The elements of a

story should be important, interesting in themselves. Such, at least, is Mr, STEVENSON'S view. " In the idealists " summary practice—looking always at " the characters and the passion, getting " over the ground, despising detail, and " appealing to tho strong and common " sentiments directly—I contend that " we get in more of men and more of " life. While tho realist, with his ner " vous shrinking from commonplace " sentiments, with his studious devo " tion to material facts, to verbal in-

" genuities, and to unexpected dis

" closures of man's stupidity and de " pravity and life's unpleasantnesses, " expresses less, and that less important " of both." In other words, if an author appeals to strong and common senti- ments, literature will be pure, and it will be more forcible and more lasting than anything that is composed by resorting to artificial devices for stimulating an unhealthy interest in the work.

ITowever true it may bo in certain special sonses that " tho individual "withers" while "the world is more "and moro," it cannot be said that literary productions evince any decay of our interest in the individual or of tho individual's interest in himself. There are, on the contrary, convincing proofs that the private life, habits, feel- ings, and character of our felloe creatures aro matters concerning which contemporary curiosity is peculiarly keon. And not only is it common to find a gratification in discovering what other men eat and drink and think, what thoy wear and iiow they behave 1 themselves ; it is becoming equally common to find a gratification in publishing such information concerning oneself. Tho same instinct which causes the supply and demand of society journals and social gossip causes the demand and supply of tho auto- biography and the Journal Intime.

The immaculate hero or heroiuo of . romance described in the third person is giving place to the imperfect fellow-being of reality revealed in the first. After having generations of analysers of imaginary characters

and sentiments in the shape of

)

dramatists and novelists, we have reached the generation of the intro spectionist and moi-spectatem: Wo cannot, indeed, always bo sure that the self-revelation is entirely candid, but it cannot be denied that, so long as we believe it candid, wo find it interesting. This Ego literature, which

is so maiked a characteristic of late years, makes its earliest appearance in the 'essays of Mos.Aif.s_, where it provoked much ridicule among the contemporary critics, who thought, as Fieuch critics aro particularly apt to think, chiefly by precedent. The result bos amply justified the chevalier. His personal experiences were really, after all, of some account in the eyes of the world at large. The world is never offended, it is, on the contrary, charmed with this form of egoism. It keeps its indignation for the egoism of incompetence. Taken on the whole, the garrulous PEP.S, of diary fame, is a greater favourite than the model folks

Why modern times should thus in- creasingly prize both gossip and self rovelation, is by no menus obvious. Why should tho American íeporter, armed with note-book and telescope, dog a newly-married president in order that 00,000,000 of his fellow-men may know his goings-out and comings-in Î Similarly, wiry should a busy world care for the feelings and ambitions of that rather pert young lady MARIE BASHKIIITSE-r ? Tho only conclusion "which commonds itself is that conven- tion and fashion are growing unbear- ably tyrannous, that they aro rendering all social inteicouiso artificial anti monotonous, and that theroforo men delight to pierce below tlio surface, in order to find that vaiioty and naivete which human nature after nil desires. According to OLIVER WENDELL HOLMES, when John talks to Thomas, there are six of thom : John as ho appears to Thomas, as ho appears to John, and as he appears to his Maker. Tho fault of modern society is that John and Thomas, by tacit understanding, pie tond to bo whatever fashion dictates. The surface is in each case sham, and they both aliko know it. If, therefore, John can see Thomas moro truly by tho sidelight of gossip, or if Thomas will

reveal himself in a book of "Con " fessions," in " Itocolloctions," in a diary or an autobiography, John secures several delightful sensations at once. He gets nearer tho truth, which is n good thing in itself and the legitimate end of cmiosity ; he can form a fairer comparativo estimato of his own virtues ; and ho can rojoice to find that certain of his own peculiar shortcomings havo been all along shared by that Thomas in whom ho had sus- pected nothing of tho kind. Despite the isolating barriers sot up by social arrangements, man really craves to thoroughly understand, and to bo in tho completfst sympathy with, his fellows. If. therefore, tho fellow-man chooses to open liia heart and mind in an un coloured nanativo of his own porsonal experiences, the narrative will bo de- voured with uncommon eagerness, and scarcely any display of vanity or vico

existed few greater rascals than BEN VEN-TO CELLINI, yet no ono lends his autobiography tlnough without some- what affectionatoly concluding that he was a very fino and interesting rascal. Wo can largely endure tho coarseness and what is dignified as tho " verso " of WHITMAN, for tho sako of the unflinching candour with which ho exposes what ho calls his " robust "

soul. Increase of civil freedom and spread of education, it may bo added, have done much to intensify a sense of personal, as opposed to communal, existence, and this individualism is naturally breaking out moro and moro iu memoirs, diaries, and the like.

These remarks havo been chiefly, prompted by tho recently published diary of MAWE BASUKIIÎ.SEFK, a work which, Uko Robert Elsmere, owes much of its increasing voguo to tho commenda- tions of Mr. GLADSTONE. Though we do not consider Mr. GLADSTONE altogether fitted for any form of dictatoiship, in matters literary he should bo no small authority, and ho has found something strikingly valuable in this account of the experiences of a poculiar feminine mind. The writer, a Russian endowed with extraordinary artistic and social powers, gives ns-from tho ago of thirteen to twenty-four-what is mani- festly a perfectly candid record of

all her feminine mutabilities of

impulse, in love, ambition, and the rest. What preciso opinion may bo formed of tho writer will depend upon the reader ; but it is impossible to

lead without instruction tlio self-revela-

tion of so reniai kablo a- peisonality. Our authoress disspcts hoiself, ciiticises horself, admires herself, falls in love wijth herself, or hates hoiself, with a simple candour as delightful ns it is imirjue. Sho is a young lady who yearns to be at ono and tho samo tipio .the queen of society, the queen otiltho stago, the female MICHAEL A$g!E_çv in fact tho ne jútts vitra in every artistic region. This ogoism may be common, but it is not common to find it possessed by one who really was so much of a fenmlo CiticinoN, and still less common to find it oponly avowed and all its shifting impulses rnthlossly analysed. Nor is it common to find a child of fourteen capable of saying that hor own diary " is at lenst " iuteiesting as a human document," If we aro right in intimating that there is developing itself a new spirit of levolt against the oxcessivo domination of convention, and a spirit in favour of a moro sympathetic social intercourse, one of its clearest indications will bo found, if not in the writing of this diary, at least in tho eagerness with which the rending public welcomes it.
